ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed knowledge of more Hispanic writers and stories. I also learned more vocabulary and culture.
A lot of vocabulary and verb tenses
Taking the class everyday really improved my speaking skills! I also learned how to use different verb structures.
I learned about grammatical structures, vocabulary, and a little about culture. I also had more practice speaking in this class than prior high school classes.
I developed greater proficiency in speaking, listening, and writing, and understanding Spanish.
I developed the skills of speaking in the various Spanish past tenses. I also began to understand the culture that goes into speaking the Spanish Language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Less focus on readings and vocab

I think the strength is the amount of material that it goes through - we covered a lot of material, especially grammar, but it never felt like too much. The weakness is how little reading/engagement there was, especially how trivial the writing assignments are. I think there could have been analytical writing about the reading we did. It was too structured around specific grammar structures and specific ways of speaking.

The grading is structured in a strict manner. This is a reflection of L3, not necessarily the Professor. Quizzes and tests are almost worth the same amount. Not only that, it is incredibly easy to lose points.
The reading of Relato de un Nufrago was a little bit too fast. Also, sometimes there were too many assessments all at once.
The readings and the novel used in class were covered minimally and at an excessively fast pace.
One strength of the course was that it met every day, but I felt that we should have communicated in Spanish at all times for a more immersive experience.
The strength of this course is that it meets every day. Weakness is excessive work that just gets annoying and makes me lose the fun of learning the language.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It's good to learn all the grammar and vocab before doing L4.
Yes because I got a lot out of the course and feel much more comfortable speaking Spanish.
Yes, as long as they are willing to put in a considerable amount of effort in order to improve their Spanish.
Yes if they want to learn a new language. You just have to suck it up and commit to it.
